metadata.title: Best Tech YouTube Tools 2025: Cameras, B-Roll & Editing
metadata.description: Essential tools for tech YouTubers. Cinema cameras, product photography setups, and editing workflows for tech reviews.

hero.headline: Best YouTube Tools for Tech Creators in 2025
hero.subheadline: Create MKBHD-quality tech content with professional cameras, lighting, and editing workflows.

sections.content: Tech YouTube demands premium production value. Viewers expect cinematic B-roll, perfect product shots, and polished editing. The good news is you don't need MKBHD's budget to create professional tech content. Here's what you need to start and scale your tech channel.

content.title: Cinema-Quality Camera
content.description: Sony A7/FX series, Canon R5/R6, or Blackmagic for that shallow depth of field tech look.

content.title: Product Lighting
content.description: Soft, controlled lighting for product shots. LED panels, softboxes, and reflectors.

content.title: Motion Control
content.description: Sliders, gimbals, or motorized turntables for smooth product reveals.

sections.title: Filming Tech Reviews
content: Plan your B-roll shots before filming
Shoot at low angles for drama
Capture both wide and detail shots

sections.title: Tech Content Advantages
content: High CPM due to tech-savvy audience
Early access and review units from brands

faq.question: Do I need an expensive camera for tech reviews?
faq.answer: You need good video quality, but mid-range cameras work fine. A Sony A6400 or Canon R10 with good lighting beats an expensive camera with poor lighting.

faq.question: How do tech YouTubers get review units?
faq.answer: Build an audience first. Once you have consistent views and quality content, reach out to PR teams. Start with smaller brands, work up to major companies.

faq.question: What makes tech B-roll look professional?
faq.answer: Shallow depth of field, smooth camera movement, dramatic lighting, slow motion, and clean backgrounds. Motion control (sliders, gimbals) elevates production value.

faq.question: What editing software do tech YouTubers use?
faq.answer: Premiere Pro is most common, followed by DaVinci Resolve. Final Cut Pro for Mac users. DaVinci is free with professional color grading built in.
